edu.udel.cis.vsl.sarl.ideal.simplify

Class LinearSolver

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.udel.cis.vsl.sarl.ideal.simplify.LinearSolver

  • public class LinearSolver
extends java.lang.Object

    Simplifies a constant map. This take as input a map which associates constant values to Monics. Some of these monics may be instances of Polynomial, in which case they will be in pseudo-primitive form: no constant term, leading coefficient is positive, leading coefficient is 1 (for real type), or GCD of absolute value of coefficients is 1 (for integer type). We will use the word "polynomial" to refer to all entries in the map, whether or not they are instances of Polynomial. The Monics which are not instances of Polynomial may be considered a polynomial with one term which has a coefficient of 1.

    It simplifies this map by performing Gaussian elimination (aka, Gauss-Jordan elimination) on the coefficient matrix formed by the terms, i.e., the "variables" are considered to be the Monics which occur in the terms and the "coefficients" are the monomial coefficients of those Monics.

    Specifically, it separates out the integer and the real entries and works on each separately. In each case, it constructs a matrix in which the rows correspond to map entries and columns correspond to the monics of the terms (of the appropriate type) which occur anywhere in the map. The entry in a column is the coefficient of that monic in the polynomial which occurs as the key in the map entry. It then performs Gaussian elimination on these matrices to reduce to reduced row echelon form. It then re-constructs the maps in this reduced form.

    There is an extra column on the right of the matrix for the constant associated to the polynomial.

    If an inconsistency exists ( for example, X+Y maps to 0, X maps to 0, Y maps to 1) in the map, this will be discovered in the elimination. In this case, the boolean value false is returned by method reduce. True is returned if there are no problems.
